## GAD-7 vs PAAS

Are you grappling with the harmonization of the Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment (GAD-7) and the Paternal Antenatal Attachment Scale (PAAS)? ‘Harmony’ is here to aid you! The term 'GAD-7 vs PAAS' triggers the need for comparing and matching the items in these two distinct psychological instruments. Making use of the advanced natural language processing and generative AI models, Harmony streamlines this task, immensely saving your time and efforts. ## Why use Harmony for 'GAD-7 vs PAAS'? When it comes to GAD-7 vs PAAS, Harmony proves to be an invaluable tool for psychologists. This powerful software doesn’t just offer a systematic comparison, it provides a percentage match between each GAD-7 and PAAS item. Moreover, it can review instruments in different languages, further broadening its utility. Its user-friendly interface lets you select instruments from the built-in database or upload your own in PDF format. ## How to Use Harmony for 'GAD-7 vs PAAS'? To leverage Harmony's capabilities in the 'GAD-7 vs PAAS' analysis, simply visit its web interface at https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app. Whether it's exploring the seven-item GAD-7 assessment that gauges the severity of generalized anxiety disorder over the past two weeks, or the PAAS 1-item scale capturing feelings towards the developing baby, Harmony makes your research process a breeze. Save your valuable research time by leaving the tiring harmonization process to Harmony – your go-to tool for 'GAD-7 vs PAAS'. Make the smart move today!

## Compare the items in GAD-7 English and PAAS

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just PAAS into Harmony</a> - compare PAAS with other instruments


## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
